looking at this again, I think this logic is wrong.

suppose deleteFilter is `["a", "b"]`, and the list of namespaces is `["b"]`. this will incorrectly skip deleting `["b"]`, since it only looks at the first element of `deleteFilter`.

probably this `continue` should be outside of the inner loop?
Good catch, thanks. Fixed logic.
maybe return after this too?
or maybe not. but does `List()` return [] or nil on error?
I agree with the original comment.  return added.
I don't like that we're returning strings here.  Can we return something more strongly typed please?

It's actually just returning whatever the loadbalancer status has, which is a string because it could either be an IP or hostname and there's no type that captures both properly https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/blob/master/pkg/api/types.go#L1237
I'd prefer even a relatively dumb wrapper, along the lines you mention.  Anything other than a vanilla string would be an improvement.
Hmm Why? a list of strings is simple no? IMO a type is useful if it adds value, either in the form of validation or type checking. Cloaking a string in a type isn't much of an improvement?
Good to note what it's return values are.  And not have them be a string :-)
Yeah unless you want me to invent some adhoc type for this i think we're stuck with the string in the api object because of the reason mentioned above
My point was that the return value of this function needs a name, and/or a non-string type.

Not sure i understand, can you suggest something concrete? I'm pulling out strings from the apitype, i feel like this is not what you're asking for:

```
type addressStruct struct {
    addresses []string
}
```

but that's what it sounds like you're asking for :)

Someone reading the function header would have no idea what the string return value would contain, unless they read through the code.

What I was suggesting is one of the following instead, approximately, in increasing order of my preference:

```
func waitForIngressAddress(c *client.Client, ns, ingName string, timeout time.Duration) (address string, error)
```

```
type address string
...
func waitForIngressAddress(c *client.Client, ns, ingName string, timeout time.Duration) (address, error)
```

you never check whether an error occurred or not. so if the endpoint fails to startup, the error is lost and you continue anyway.

(also nit: misspelled "endpoint")
You can use `netutil.CanonicalAddr` for this
It doesn't support WSS
Ah, gotcha

if the poll times out, and thus some pods aren't deleted, the fact that it timed out won't be reported, which may be misleading when debugging failures. it'd probably be good to include this error + report any nondeleted pods? or maybe the timeout should take precedence?
Err isn't shadowed - the poll error would be returned.
Corrected the message so that it indicates it's a poll duration thing.
This won't work on GKE.

`getMasterHost()` is a bad pattern that snuck in with the `etcd_failure.go` test, and unfortunately, everything that uses it has to to be excluded from GKE. You'll note that `addon_update.go` and `etcd_failure.go` skip GKE as well.
Just exclude it for now and we'll figure it out later.

I found the cause. Getting pods back based on label may fail due to timing issue. Therefore, I created `waitForPodsWithLabel()` to keep polling pods with label `run=<rc name>` for a certain time until it returns more than 0 pods. This seems to work and I'll test again just to make sure.

This isn't guaranteed to scale.  300 might start in 10 minutes, but can you guarantee 10000 pods would?  This function is used in tests that run against a cluster that could be of any size and it should be able to pass.  The old looping mechanism didn't care about how long it took, only that there was progress.  Having a hard time limit makes this function less reliable for different pod counts.  I'd prefer going back to tracking progress vs arbitrary timeout
I don't think we should worry about 10000 pods yet.

There's no reason to not allow for it. We run 100 pods/node on 23 physical nodes (2300 pods) and with performance regressions we've seen, only see about 3 pods start/sec (if the math in #8119 is correct).  That would be roughly 700 seconds, or >10 minutes, for all pods to start.  A hard time limit isn't the right path here.
We're currently targeting 30 pods/node.
Again, no reason to prevent running at larger scale.

+1 to rrati please **do not** put in a blind 10 minute time-out, we do indeed check much greater densities then 30 on our end. 

@fgrzadkowski, @gmarek
Suggestion for timeout: 30 seconds + 2 seconds per pod?
Done

comments.body: nit: love the method comment, but Go style says comments should start with the method name (e.g. "checkAllResponses issues GETs ...")
Done.
suggest splitting this out into another function that just waits for pods so we can, say, wait for 50% of the pods or something down the line.
Done

Listing all pods every 5s was exactly the thing a lot of our work was done to avoid, since it places quite a bit of load on the system by itself :)

Unsure how much context you have about similar code, but another way to achieve this would be to setup a reflector, eg: https://github.com/GoogleCloudPlatform/kubernetes/blob/master/pkg/kubelet/config/apiserver.go#L43. A controller is an even higher abstraction, but I think a reflector should do for this. You can then poll the store.
There is the same pattern in RunRC function. Since nobody complains let's leave it as it is now. When we decide to get rid of listing pods from e2e tests we will do it in both places.
To avoid confusing why not just call this stop? since there is a delete operation as well, but it doesn't resize. can you also log the delete rc name/namespace since you do it randomly above?

AFAIK we want to get rid of stop, so let's call this delete.

For more context https://github.com/GoogleCloudPlatform/kubernetes/pull/7432#discussion_r29259589
Either expose this so I can control the resize to return without waiting, or force everyone to wait and delete waitForRCPodsRunning? Otherwise I'm not sure how I'd use the 2 together

I think we should keep such methods as simple as possible ie. when someone is writing e2e test he shouldn't care about waiting timeout. Also it's only e2e so we don't care that much about performance, so let's leave it as it is now. Function waitForRCPodsRunning is just factored out from ResizeRC to make code more readable and may be used in a different methods in util.go.
Can we be sure that before we call waitForRCPdosRunning all pods are already created/deleted?
Yes, otherwise resizer.Resize returns error.

I was using kubectl on the path before specifically so that we could pick up the version of kubectl bundled with gcloud when running the tests with the GKE provider. I think this change will force us to always use the version bundled with the tests, which isn't representative of the typical GKE experience.

I'm a little confused. `hack/ginkgo-e2e.sh` was setting `PATH` to include the directory containing `e2e`, which as best as I understand, will result in the version of `kubectl` from the release being used. (One difference is that kubectl.sh tacks on some extra args for gke, I guess.)

Hmm. Maybe my intent wasn't being achieved in practice. 

/cc @jlowdermilk who helped me configure this when we originally rewrote these tests.

Actually, we have been testing gke with the version of kubectl from the release. I think backwards compatibility is now the thing we need to test more than future breakages, so we should probably use the bundled kubectl.

Edit: we want to test backwards compatibility for gke-test, but we do want early warning of future breakages, so we should keep gke-ci using the release version. TL;DR, using release version here is fine, provided we overwrite `PATH` to pick up the gcloud bundled version for gke/gke-test.
OK, I will revert this change and open an issue (or maybe a bug) to make sure that gke/gke-test use the gcloud version instead. It's probably best to fix that in a separate PR.

Looking at `cluster/kubectl.sh`, it looks like we can set the `KUBECTL_PATH` env variable for the gke/gke-test projects, and then it'll actually use the right version. So I'll keep the change to use cluster/kubectl.sh rather than kubectl directly? Unless there's still a strong reason not to.
SGTM. That will let us use the latest build kubectl for gke-ci and the gcloud-bundled one for gke-test|staging|prod.

comments.body: Once you sync please use this func in https://github.com/GoogleCloudPlatform/kubernetes/blob/master/test/e2e/util.go#L727
Why wouldn't we want \* vs. just latencies?
I think there is a misunderstanding. I'm asking to use getMetrics function in getLatencyMetrics function.
Ah, yes.  I misunderstood.  I'll put getMetrics into getLatencyMetrics
I don't understand this - why do you queue for pod lists here? Why not use watch-based cache and just check how many items we have?

The section checking that the controller is submitting the expected number of pods is using the same queue as the later section checking the states.  Here it is only looking at the total number of pops but it's not really using any more resources since it's a shared queue.  If a watch would work for both I'm open to looking at it, but I don't see the point in using a watch here if I still need the queue later.
@fgrzadkowski , if we used the Informer pattern the question would consistent time-based sampling.
Let's go one step back. Why do you need queue at all? What was wrong with the previous approach where we were just listing pods?

Pods are starting while we are waiting for the pods to be submitted from the rc.  To get an accurate pod start rate for the whole test we need to be able to query the pod starts while the rc is still submitting pods.  The previous approach would lost about 1/2 the pod starts because by the time the rc had finished submitting the pods a number of them had started already.

Is it bad? Have you found some scenarios where this data helped you debug them? If there are some concrete good use-cases then let's add this. Otherwise let's rethink this, because it adds complexity.

Pods starting while the rc is submitting pods isn't bad.  In fact that is what I would expect to happen.  However with the old method there was no way to see the whole pod start curve because part of the data wasn't reported while the rc was submitting pods.  The csv file this creates can be used to generate graphs, etc

Let me rephrase - adding complexity just for the sake of generating file should be avoided. However if there is a real life example where this could be useful (e.g. during your recent debugging it'd save you X minutes) I'm all for it.
I'm just trying to understand why are we doing it.

Currently I use scripts to do the work that rob has added. The scripts generated the graphs that led to a number of the issues we started logging back in Feb+March.  Ideally, I would like to push this data to Prometheus to have a simple rolled up cluster response curve to an impulse event (density).   We considered the "push" as a post process, and anyone can consume .csv and just go. 

This gives us a rough swag, and if the slope of the response curve falls below a certain threshold we start rooting to determine where the issue is.
For my own education - how can we use these debugging data? I only used it using `go tool pprof`.
A very simple example is we can see a large spike in the # of go-routines in cases where we expect it to hold steady.
But this is a one-time snapshot, so it will not show us diffs. Am I missing something?
Yeah we only have a before and after snapshot atm, so it's pretty course grained.
Can you please add a comment that you read all available elements without sleeping? It was not obvious for me.
done
Can you please drop a TODO to improve this parsing in the future? :)
Done.
I didn't understand the "quantile" stuff (here and in the other function) -- can you add a comment?
Done
Add a comment with an example "body" that you are going to parse?
Done.
nit: Does the 'Obj' suffix serve any purpose here?  I'd prefer plain 'namespace'.
Well... it clarified that its a object , not  a **string**  .  easy to assume "namespace" is a string typ.e   Still prefer name space or ok---?

Do you really need to explicitly create the namespace?  I'm a bit vague on how all of this works internally.  I suspect that you can just decide on the namespace names here, along the lines of how test/e2e/services.go currently works.
Yes you do but there are ways to launch kube so n's is created dynamically.  Anyways for tests it's good to do this step by step don't you think?
To clarify : some clusters might configure the create namespace automatically feature differently.  Imo We shouldn't rely on that for e2es.. Sounds ok?

comments.body: This will always be a whole number, since we're printing the timeout, not elapsed time. I'm fine with `%.2f` if you feel strongly about seeing the `.00`, but I don't think it's a bug :)
This way you are free to change to timeout constant and then something reasonable will happen. Happy to change it to `%.0f` if you prefer.

`%.2f` is fine. FWIW, `time.Duration` has an intelligent value printer, so printing the duration directly with `%v` also results in reasonable output of the form `30s, 5m0s`, etc, though the output was temporarily borked prior to #5134. Still, having it consistently print the timeout in seconds is worthwhile, so merged.
This func looks like an almost exact dupe of the previous one with a different success condition. Can you consolidate the shared logic into a helper function?
Moved shared logic into waitForPodCondition.

util.go file.
